newsitem.title: ROMANIA: ROMANIA GOVERNMENT BACKTRACKS, REDUCES ROAD TAX.
newsitem.headline: ROMANIA GOVERNMENT BACKTRACKS, REDUCES ROAD TAX.

text.p: Romania's government has lowered a proposed road tax levied to patch up the country's potholed highways after protests by opposition politicians, motorists and car makers.

A decree issued by the new centrist coalition late on Wednesday reduced the tax for larger vehicles. Some cars would have been assessed at an annual rate equivalent to $200, more than twice the average monthly salary.

A government statement said the tax was intended to complement an existing law creating a fund to upgrade roads. Data show around 70 percent of the country's 14,500-km (9,000-mile) road network is in bad need of repair.
Under the new rules, assessments for vehicles with engines of up to 1,500 ccs remained unchanged at the equivalent of $7 and middle-range cars were also left at the previous rate.
Owners of vehicles exceeding 3,200 ccs were the big winners and will now be assessed the equivalent of $85.
Pensioners are assessed an annual tax of $7 but ministers inserted a provision limiting each person to a single vehicle to prevent "sales of convenience" to avoid higher rates.
Motorists caught without a tax sticker will be hit with a fine 10 times their assessment.
Car makers and importers had denounced the original proposal, saying existing taxes had already eaten into sales and brought their industry to the brink of collapse.
The leftist opposition submitted a censure motion to parliament but it was easily defeated. REUTER
